channel.title: Webserver Installation Halp CentOS 5.2
channel.description:
So, I need help with setting up and configuring a CentOS 5.2 webserver.
I've been through about 8 guides, and since linux is annoying and inconsistent, I run into many problems.
First off, I don't have access to the initial installation of linux, meaning, I am only welcome to whatever comes with the minimal server installation of CentOS. (I say this because most of the guides I have looked at refer you to that).
No GUI either.
Thanks in advanced.

item.title: Webserver Installation Halp CentOS 5.2
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

- Kernel + applications 18% 45.23 MB

And that is running a php, apache and mysql server.

item.title: Webserver Installation Halp CentOS 5.2
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“runescape3dude, post:38, topic:254611”][quote author=Pwnd link=topic=336443.msg2671757#msg2671757 date=1234850066]
runescape, those aren’t INSTALLED sizes.
[/quote]

I thought he meant download size… I will download one and install it with just a web server, I will see how much space it needs.

Checked:
555M with no packages that I know of.[/quote]Which is huge for no packages.

Those are if you can download all the bullshit to the computer through the installer rather than putting everything on it’s own DVD.

Read full topic

item.title: Webserver Installation Halp CentOS 5.2
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

[quote=“T4_, post:14, topic:254611”][quote author=runescape3dude link=topic=336443.msg2614587#msg2614587 date=1230955325]
Ubuntu is easy to install as a webserver. Get the minimal CD (like 9.5MB) shove it in your drive. Select the packages you want, ftp, php, apache, mysql, pma then you can select a gui if you want. Then it goes and downloads all the files you selected from the internet.
[/quote]

The minimal pkg is ~300MB. But, nevertheless, CentOS should have done that same feature during install. There is a LAMP option.[/quote]

32-bit PC (x86)

*

  Ubuntu 8.10 "Intrepid Ibex" Minimal CD 9.9MB
*

  Ubuntu 8.04 "Hardy Heron" Minimal CD 9.5MB*
*

  Ubuntu 7.10 "Gutsy Gibbon" Minimal CD 9.1MB
*

  Ubuntu 7.04 "Feisty Fawn" Minimal CD 8.4MB
*

  Ubuntu 6.10 "Edgy Eft" Minimal CD 8.4MB
*

  Ubuntu 6.06 "Dapper Drake" Minimal CD 7.4MB*

64-bit PC (amd64)

*

  Ubuntu 8.10 "Intrepid Ibex" Minimal CD 10MB
*

  Ubuntu 8.04 "Hardy Heron" Minimal CD 9.6MB*
*

  Ubuntu 7.10 "Gutsy Gibbon" Minimal CD 9.1MB
*

  Ubuntu 7.04 "Feisty Fawn" Minimal CD 8.4MB
*

  Ubuntu 6.10 "Edgy Eft" Minimal CD 8.4MB
*

  Ubuntu 6.06 "Dapper Drake" Minimal CD 7.4MB*

Read full topic

item.title: Webserver Installation Halp CentOS 5.2
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

[quote=“llib, post:27, topic:254611”][quote author=adamp40 link=topic=336443.msg2615059#msg2615059 date=1230980847]

Ubuntu is Crap as it will only run a nicely Speced PC!
If Pwnd is using CentOS hes using a pretty crap PC.

If your running a Webserver you would burn out half your CPU and RAM by just running Ubuntu.

thb the best way to run a webserver is “aquire” (not buy) Windows Home Server
[/quote]

As far as using Ubuntu as a webserver:

System information as of Sat Jan 10 09:10:01 EST 2009

  System load: 0.0               Memory usage: 15%   Processes:       62
  Usage of /:  12.9% of 8.73GB   Swap usage:   0%    Users logged in: 0

  Graph this data and manage this system at https://landscape.canonical.com/
Last login: Sat Jan 10 08:56:45 2009

^hdd I robed out of my old xbox xD^

Yea its just burning up shitloads of resources just sitting there -.-’

I can’t hear that computer running at all.

As far as a webserver goes…as long as you know how to use the distros package manager (why I picked ubuntu) does it really matter?[/quote]

It is actually probably using very little ram(<100MB), as it just caches a whole lot for faster access.

Read full topic

item.title: Webserver Installation Halp CentOS 5.2
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

For some reason, when I switched my DL380 to Win 2k3 enterprise, it’s fans managed to slow right down to minimal, compared to the 100% at all times with ubuntu. However, I loved ubuntu so much on it, because I could SSH to it from school and write/run programs and browse the net through it. The only decent thing Windows Server has is IIS (6.0 is the best) it is a very easy to configure web server.

And what is with the STL2 server… It’s hard disks run constantly at full speed. I am pretty sure they are the 15K ones because they sound a lot higher pitched than the ones in the DL380. Is it safe to put a sock in front of them to block the noise?

Also, the best server I have ever had was the computer I found outside a hospital. It has 512MB ram, 600MHZ P2(slew), 50GB HDD, Windows server 2003, Raid 0, Dual networking… etc. + You cannot hear it.

Read full topic

item.title: Webserver Installation Halp CentOS 5.2
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:23, topic:254611”][quote author=adamp40 link=topic=336443.msg2615059#msg2615059 date=1230980847]
If Pwnd is using CentOS hes using a pretty crap PC.
[/quote]

I run CentOS on a box that would shit on your desktop, eat it again and proclaim it delicious…[/quote]

Yes, Linux runs on ancient machines and bleeding edge ones too. My Q6600 is running at 5GHz stable on Debian. (Using phase change for coolant). Not that Q6600 is bleeding edge anymore, but it still proves Linux is run on powerful systems.

Read full topic

thb the best way to run a webserver is “aquire” (not buy) Windows Home Server[/quote]You’re an idiot.
